title: 111_hr4897
content: The Act may be cited as the "Drivers Accelerated Interest Deductibility Act of 2010" or the "Drivers AID Act". Congress acknowledges the importance of a strong automotive industry for the economic health of the United States, with automotive sales historically contributing significantly to retail spending and providing financial security for many Americans. Sales figures from 2006 to 2008 showed fluctuations but remained above the indicator of a robust industry. The automotive industry saw fluctuations in sales from 2006 to 2008, with numbers ranging from 17,500,000 units to 14,200,000 units. Since June 2008, sales have averaged less than 10,000,000 units annually, falling below the robust industry threshold of 13,000,000 units. The annual revenue for new automobile dealers in 2008 was $28,800,000 on average. The automotive new vehicle dealers industry in the United States had substantial contributions to the national economy in 2008. The total sales revenue for new automobile dealers was $576 billion, making up 14.6% of total retail sales. There were 1,057,500 employees in new-vehicle dealerships, earning an average of $48,963 per year, generating a national payroll of over $52 billion. In the United States, new vehicle dealerships had an average of 53 employees earning $48,963 per year, totaling over $52 billion in national payroll. A well-capitalized dealer network is crucial for automobile manufacturers' success, supporting the national economic interest. Sales of new vehicles rely on consumer confidence and incentives, emphasizing the importance of reducing the cost of capital for vehicle purchases. The deduction of nonmortgage interest payments, like automobile loan debt, for Federal income tax purposes was in place for 73 years until Congress ended it in 1986 with the Tax Reform Act. This change had a positive impact on the new-vehicle dealer industry, strengthening the automotive manufacturing sector and the national economy. The Tax Reform Act in 1986 ended the deduction for nonmortgage interest payments, including those for acquiring a passenger car or light truck. Section 163(h) of the Internal Revenue Code was amended to include a new subparagraph (G) for qualified vehicle interest based on the national unemployment rate. The qualified vehicle interest is defined as any interest properly chargeable on indebtedness incurred in acquiring a qualified vehicle and properly allocable to a 36-month period. The deduction for nonmortgage interest payments was eliminated by the Tax Reform Act of 1986. Section 163(h) of the Internal Revenue Code now includes a new subparagraph (G) for qualified vehicle interest based on the national unemployment rate. The qualified vehicle interest is defined as any interest properly chargeable on indebtedness incurred in acquiring a qualified vehicle and properly allocable to a 36-month period, with a limit of $5,000. The term 'qualified vehicle' refers to a motor vehicle acquired for personal use by the taxpayer, with no payment made under a specific act, and the original use commencing with the taxpayer. The term 'qualified vehicle' refers to a motor vehicle for personal use by the taxpayer, made by a manufacturer, with a gross vehicle weight rating of 6,000 pounds or less, and classified as a passenger automobile or light truck. The term 'motor vehicle' refers to any vehicle manufactured primarily for use on public streets with at least 4 wheels. The terms 'automobile', 'passenger automobile', 'light truck', and 'manufacturer' have specific meanings as defined in regulations. The term 'motor vehicle' refers to a vehicle for public street use with at least 4 wheels. Terms like 'automobile', 'passenger automobile', 'light truck', and 'manufacturer' are defined by the EPA for Clean Air Act purposes. The average national unemployment rate is calculated as the average of monthly rates in a calendar quarter. The amendment allows a deduction for qualified vehicle interest in computing adjusted gross income, effective for vehicles acquired on or after January 1, 2008.
